thread.title: Giants share emotional victory with their ailing tight end
thread.title_full: Giants share emotional victory with their ailing tight end | The Seattle Times

author: Seattle Times staff
title: Giants share emotional victory with their ailing tight end
text:
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Less than 24 hours after one of their biggest victories in years, there was a good feeling in the New York Giants’ locker room.
The team is suddenly leading the dismal NFC East with a 3-2 record following an uplifting 30-27 triumph over San Francisco on Sunday night.
The victory was special, and there was another special moment Monday. Game balls were given out and one went to tight end Daniel Fells, who is hospitalized with a case of MRSA. The Giants had dedicated the game to him and they shared their feeling in an online conversation.
“Everybody was able to cheer him and to try to make him feel better and he was very nice in saying he watched the game and liked the way we finished,” coach Tom Coughlin said.
  Fells has made progress against the infection the past three days and is feeling better after getting a couple of good nights of sleep. 
“He was very gracious about receiving a game ball and he told his teammates what he felt about them based on their games. It was nice,” Coughlin said.
Charles all done KANSAS CITY, Mo. — Chiefs running back Jamaal Charles will miss the remainder of the season with a torn ACL in his right knee.
The star running back hurt his knee in the third quarter Sunday against Chicago. An MRI on Monday confirmed the tear.
Charles, a four-time Pro Bowl selection, was making a cut deep in Bears territory Sunday when his right knee buckled at a gruesome angle. 
NOTES • Twitter accounts for websites Deadspin and SB Nation were suspended by the social media platform Monday night after the NFL filed notices related to their use of copyrighted video highlights. The NFL told The Associated Press it requested Twitter “disable links to more than a dozen pirated NFL game videos and highlights that violate the NFL’s copyright,” adding that it did not request any Twitter accounts be disabled.
• The Cardinals rolled into West Virginia on the heels of blowout victory at Detroit, settling in at The Greenbrier resort. Rather than fly back to Arizona, then have to fly to Pittsburgh a few days later, the Cardinals opted to stay on the East Coast.
• Sheldon Richardson practiced with the Jets for the first time since the preseason after an NFL-issued suspension for violating the league’s substance abuse policy cost the defensive end the first four games of the season.
• Tight end Antonio Gates has been added to the Chargers’ active roster after serving a four-game suspension for testing positive for a performance enhancing drug. 
• The Cardinals have signed veteran defensive end/outside linebacker Dwight Freeney to a one-year contract, according to a source. The move comes after the Cardinals’ top outside pass rusher, Alex Okafor , went down with a calf injury. The 35-year-old Freeney, a seven-time Pro Bowl player and three-time first team All Pro, ranks 21st in the NFL in career sacks with 111½.
• The Bills announced receiver Sammy Watkins (right calf) is expected to return after missing two games.
• Jaguars quarterback Blake Bortles sprained his throwing shoulder Sunday. The team says Bortles suffered a “Grade 1 AC joint sprain” early in the game but played through it. Coach Gus Bradley adds, “We think he should be in good shape.”
• Colts quarterback Andrew Luck was a full participant in practice Monday for the first time in two weeks. Luck is still day to day with a sore right shoulder and had been limited in practice.
• Dolphins special-teams coordinator Darren Rizzi has been promoted to assistant head coach by interim head coach Dan Campbell .
